dt: {bc}suppressed, altered, or deleted as objectionable {bc}subjected to censorship

dt.t: … the annual announcement of the list of {wi}censored{/wi} stories is a genuine media event …
… during the nineteenth century intellectuals would meet to read a variety of foreign newspapers, searching for information withheld from the heavily {wi}censored{/wi} press.

shortdef: suppressed, altered, or deleted as objectionable : subjected to censorship

dt: {bc}to examine in order to suppress {dx_def}see {dxt|suppress||2}{/dx_def} or delete anything considered objectionable

shortdef: to examine in order to suppress or delete anything considered objectionable; also : to suppress or delete as objectionable

dt: {bc}the act or action of refraining from expressing something (such as a thought, point of view, or belief) that others could deem objectionable

dt.t: What effects does {wi}self-censorship{/wi} have on the accuracy and predictive validity of opinion polls?

aq.auth: Samuel J. Best and Benjamin Radcliff

dt.t: If {wi}self-censorship{/wi} were ineffective, direct prohibition would be substituted.

utxt.t: She {wi}self-censors{/wi} her language around the children.
I know our interrogators wouldn't want us to answer that question. I feel an overwhelming need to {wi}self-censor{/wi}. {ldquo}We can't really talk about that,{rdquo} I say.

shortdef: the act or action of refraining from expressing something (such as a thought, point of view, or belief) that others could deem objectionable
